audio_descriptions.notes:
at first the screen is black and then pictures of our host tami dixon dance across the screen to the music

the first one is her as a man with a cigarette hanging out of her mouth and a white t shirt

the second her as a clown brushing her hair

the third is her with a pale wig and makeup and what appears to be blood or ketchup on her hands

the final picture is her as an older woman, applying make up

then the screen reads thank you 5 

adrienne and tami both look offscreen as they say thank you. they both return to facing the camera 

our host tami dixon, a white woman with with blonde hair, is brushing her face with make up

to her right is her guest adrienne white woman with silvery blonde hair, big green-blue eyes and a beaming
smile -- she is pulling her hair back as she speaks

the credits roll past and read
thank you five
host tami dixon
guest addrienne wehr
jingle writers tami dixon and sartje pickett
editor michael young
closed captioning karen hannon. 

the video ends with the bricolage logo

result.title: Thank You 5! Episode 10: Adrienne Wehr
result.description:
Closed captioning available for this video. 

To experience an audio described version of this episode please visit: 


Thank You 5! is a Bricolage Production Company interview show designed to engage theatre artists in simple conversations about their craft. Set in a theatre’s dressing room, TY5 host Tami Dixon asks 5 questions to some of Pittsburgh’s favorite theatre artists in order to evoke memory, dreams and meaning under the guise of an informal “pre-show” dressing room chat.

The term ‘thank you, 5’ is traditional theatre lingo spoken in theaters all over the planet. Before a show the stage manager (SM) visits each dressing room giving ‘call times’ to the actors. When the SM gives the ‘5 minutes to places’ call the actors respond with “thank you 5!”

On our guest:
Adrienne Wehr is the producer, co-creator and co-performer of the multi-disciplinary performance
art piece In the Company of Ghosts which received its world premiere by New Hazlett Theatre
in 2017 and currently resides on City of Asylum’s arts sharing network The Show Must Go
On(Line)! www.inthecompanyofghosts.com

Award-winning performer/producer, Wehr is a force in independent filmmaking. She produced
and performed in the critically acclaimed, multi award-winning indie feature The Bread, My
Sweet (aka: A Wedding for Bella), still in worldwide distribution and about to celebrate it’s 20 th
anniversary. She is a performer/producer for the award winning web series Dog Bytes:
https://www.youtube.com/user/dogbytestheseries The series was named as one of the “Best
Web Series of 2015” at Cannes 2016. She was nominated for “Best Actor” honors at Rio
Webfest in Rio De Janeiro for Dog Bytes.

For more than a decade, Wehr was Associate Producer for the Emmy award-winning
children’s television program Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood—the show that shaped
America’s values for children and was the benchmark for quality programming.
She performs for film, stage, TV and as a voice-over artist. Film credits include 20th Century
Fox’s Unstoppable directed by Tony Scott, Lionsgate’s Warrior, Kevin Smith’s Zack and Miri
Make a Porno and Dogma, Disney’s Inspector Gadget, George Romero Presents Deadtime
Stories, Riddle, Strange Girls, The Bread, My Sweet, Lightweight, The Perils of Growing
Up Flat-Chested, Lift, Progression, The Umbrella Man, Exterior; Night, The Race,
Inheritance, Breakage, A Fancy Piece of Homicide, Alone and Immaculate Reception
which premiered at Sundance 2014. www.imdb.com/name/nm0917606/

Theatre credits include: STOOP is a Verb (City of Asylum & Attack Theater); The Mercy Seat,
Death and the Maiden, Without Ruth, Inky (Off the Wall); Chicks With Dicks (Bricolage);
Becky’s New Car (The Rep); Women Beware Women, Cheapside (UnSeam’d Shakespeare);
The Ghost Sonata, Camino Real, The Royal Family, Laura, The Skin of Our Teeth (The
Acting Company); Dracula (City Theatre); world premieres of Take a Letter and gravity + grace
and the Pittsburgh premiere of Ping Chong’s The Angels of Swedenborg. She
performed/produced productions for La MaMa ETC in NYC and was a founding producer/host of
the long-lived theatrical cabaret The Dark Night Series for City Theatre in Pittsburgh. Wehr is
featured in Chris Gore’s Ultimate Film Festival Survival Guide (3rd Edition) relaying the
winning strategy behind guiding The Bread, My Sweet through its celebrated festival season
onto global distribution. She has served as a: consultant on independent filmmaking; art
director/production designer/stylist for film & media; guest teaching artist for Carnegie Mellon
University, University of Pittsburgh, Point Park University, Robert Morris University,
Pittsburgh Filmmakers; cross-disciplinary arts educator for the Carnegie Museum of Art and
at-risk communities; acting coach and professional illustrator. Her other creative disciplines
include still photography, sculpture, painting, movement theater/dance, writing, voice.
She was recipient of Women in Film and Media’s distinguished Opal Award for
Excellence in the field of Film/Media, and has been honored in the past by the
Pittsburgh Post Gazette as one of “Pittsburgh’s Fifty Finest” and “Top Cultural
Forces”, and among “40 Under 40” by Pittsburgh Magazine.

Wehr holds a Bachelor of Arts in Writing/Literature with a minor in Performing and Visual Arts
from Denison University; studied Communication Design at the Art Institute of Pittsburgh;
Production/Lighting Design, and Dance at Point Park University. Professional mentors include
Beth Claussen, Meredith Monk, Eiko and Koma, Mark Taylor, Maree ReMalia, Tome Cousin,
Maureen Fleming, Kari Margolis, Buddy Thompson, Amy Hartman, Jeffrey Bergman, Michael
Shurtleff, John Homa, Jeff Dockweiler, Jeff Monahan, Melanie Dreyer, Michelle & Robert Colt,
and Glen Gress. Facebook & LinkedIn as Adrienne Wehr, Instagram @adriennewehr

For more information about Bricolage Production Company visit: www.bricolagepgh.org
